Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: Very good photo quality; Monster 24X, 25 - 600 mm Leica lens; Power OIS image stabilization, with "active" mode for movies; 3-inch rotating LCD with 460,000 pixels, good outdoor/low light visibility; Full manual controls with RAW support, numerous ways to adjust white balance, two types of bracketing, and a customizable button and spot on the mode dial; Intelligent Auto mode does it all for you, including scene selection, face detection, blur reduction, shadow brightening, and smart sharpening; Robust performance, especially focusing and shot-to-shot speeds; Lots of scene modes and special effects, with 3D still capability; Intelligent Resolution sharpens photos, and gives you a 1.3x boost in zoom power with a minimal drop in image quality; Super fast burst mode, with ability to shoo ... t at 5.5 with continuous AF and 12 fps with single AF; Intelligent Dynamic brightens shadows (though not in all situations -- and it does nothing for highlight clipping); Records movies at 1080/60p with stereo sound and continuous autofocus using AVCHD or MPEG-4 codecs -- full manual controls available -- optical zoom and image stabilizer can be used while recording; Support for external flash, external microphone, conversion lenses and filters, and a remote shutter release cable; Above average battery life; HDMI output
Cons: Tends to clip highlights; Images have yellow/brownish cast in artificial light -- still no fluorescent white balance option; Some redeye -- no removal tool in playback mode; Long write times after a burst containing RAW photos is taken; Rainbow effect on electronic viewfinder can be distracting; Can't access memory card while camera is on a tripod; No composite A/V cable or Mac software included; Full manual on CD-ROM (it's not very user-friendly, either)
The Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 is a very good super zoom camera, and one that should be high on your shopping list. If you're a beginner who wants something simple to take photos and movies with, it can do that with ease. Enthusiasts will be pleased too, thanks to the full manual controls, expandability, and RAW support. Negatives are few, and are mostly related to highlight clipping, color accuracy in artificial lighting, and what you'll find in the box. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: Excellent 24x zoom covers 25-600mm Optical Image Stabilization Solid build Stereo microphone Articulating LCD Electronic viewfinder Power switch instead of a button Built-in hot shoe Two zoom toggles Lens hood included Rear dial is great for quick adjustments Nice, big shutter release Dual-speed zoom lever Top-deck Movie Record start button High quality Full HD video at 60p High speed video 12 fps full resolution continuous mode Mode dial is packed with 14 modes RAW and RAW+JPEG capture modes Good battery life EV control is easy to access Auto white balance does well More sophisticated noise suppression system Fast autofocus Fast shot-to-shot cycle time Mic/Remote socket HDMI port Good print quality, ran ... ging from 16x20 to 5x7 at lowest and highest ISO settings
Cons: Tends to blow out highlights Tripod socket too close to battery/card door Zoom range not as generous as some competitors Lens hood gets in the way of the flash Uncorrected RAW files have lots of chromatic aberration, and geometric distortion at wide-angle is strong (typical of long zooms, though) No sweep panorama mode Incandescent white balance is a little warm
Review Posted: 11/15/2011_ If there's still an argument to be made for the small sensor digicam, the most compelling would have to be the one made by the megazoom models. Thanks to the relatively small size of the sensor itself, you can enjoy the most versatile lenses ever crafted. From a true wide angle that embraces a small room to an impossible-to-keep-steady zoom with a macro that makes small things visible, the megazoom delivers in one lens what no other camera can. The drawback to this magic, however, is also the sensor size. Packing a lot of photo sites onto such a tiny imager means that the more sensitive ISO settings will deliver too many "false positives" per pixel, generating what we call Noise. Compounding the problem is that image processors have become as cocky as an adolescent with car keys, smoothing out that noise at the expense of detail. Last year's FZ100, Panasonic's flagship megazoom, failed to earn a Dave's Pick for just that reason. So how did Panasonic do with this year's top-of-the line FZ150? *Look and Feel*. First of all, let's applaud the company for sticking to a well-conceived design that is also solidly built. The Panasonic FZ150 body is nearly identical to the FZ100 with only some silkscreening omitted, a larger stereo microphone grill, and a new side lever on the outside of the lens barrel which can be set to focus or zoom so you can put your left hand to use. Small refinements. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I've been looking for a camera that takes great quality photos yet compact enough to carry around; this camera is the best of both worlds. I'm what you would call the casual hobbyist photographer. I actually have 2 cameras, a full size SLR and this Panasonic. For years, I carried around a compact point and shoot camera mainly out of the convenience but I was rarely satisfied with the quality of photos. The outdoor daylight photos were good but indoor photos and low light conditions were awful but I also didn't feel like carrying around a bulky full size SLR when I'm traveling, hiking etc. The problem with the point and shoot cameras is that there is no ability to adjust the settings such as the Aperture (lens opening), Shutter speed (Length of time the shutter allows lig ... ht to travel through the lens) or the ISO/ASA (film speed). Basically, the right amount of light needs to travel through the lens to prevent over exposure (too light) or under exposure (too dark). The point and shoot cameras have specific settings i.e. portrait mode, sports mode, night scenes etc but the problem with this is that the computer and sensor in the camera is controlling all of the settings and it often leads to poor quality shots. This is where the Panasonic FZ150 comes in. This camera is considered to be a compact SLR and it takes excellent photographs. It starts with a high quality Leica lens which delivers phenomenal colors and sharp pictures. This camera allows the user to manually adjust all of the settings mentioned above but it's much smaller and lighter than the full size SLR's. This camera also has a large LCD screen to review your shots and it also shoot 1080 HD video. If you're not worried about bulk, size or cost, then I would recommend you go with the full size SLR's because nothing will compare when it comes to professional looking photos. If you want a great camera that shoots all around quality photos, at a good price, and compact size, then this is the camera for you. The only drawback is that the lens is fixed on this camera, meaning you cannot switch out to a different lens for situational photography but with that said, the vast majority of folks will find that this camera and lens is more than you need. I would also recommend you buy a spare battery and a clear lens filter for around $15 to protect the lens; if you scratch the lens, your camera is done. I'm really pleased with this camera and would recommend it to anyone who finds themselves in a similar situation as mine. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: This is ALMOST a pro camera. It does EVERYTHING a pro does, but has a lower cost light sensor. This is the BEST!!!
Cons: I compare it to a full professional camera, but it costs half as much, so the light sensor isn't pro.
I LOVE IT!!! The fz150 is a hybrid bridge megazoom. Hybrid referring to the light sensor. Bridge means it's between a point and shoot and a pro camera. Mega zoom means it's lens reaches far further than other cameras (there are a few other megazooms but their image clarity isn't nearly as amazing as this one). The light sensor is amazing for not being pro-price-range, it's some kind of hybrid sensor which is better than other point and shoots, but it's not a full professional sensor because it costs half as much. This is an incredible travel camera fo ... r me because the lens is built in and i don't have to carry anything but a CPL day-filter for super bright days. I can add lenses to it, easily, but they must go on the end of the permanent lens. Also, the close-up "macro" shots are incredible, I can print a poster of a penny. I can get way up close on anything, to the point of touching the lens itself (i do use a protective lens filter so i don't scratch the lens!!!), providing there is light to take a photo. I highly recommend this camera for serious photo takers. A professional photographer should use this as a travel camera because it's light-weight compared to the huge gear you're used to carrying around and this camera has as many features as the pro cameras. The video quality, and the video features, are breath taking. I make blu-ray videos for my buddies and this is the v-logging camera of my dreams. :D
if you're a child who doesn't care what the camera does, get something pocket size and cheaper. but if you need superb pixel clarity, then get this camera. if you're a super professional, then spend 2 grand more and get a super pro camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I am replacing a Canon VIXIA HV30 for family photos and videos, as well as occasional second camera angle in 2-cam shoots. I've only had it for a week. The Panasonic delivers a lot for the money both in video and for stills. It delivers very good video quality, but not as easy to operate as dedicated video cams. The zoom for instance is 2-speed, not continuous; there's no iris ring. Focus is electric and not too precise. For family photos it appears more than adequate. I had been looking at the $1,000 range of DSLRs with interchangeable lenses, but really didn't need more than a zoom, so saved a lot. They didn't seem to provide more video functionality, and the kit lenses were quite slow. The viewfinder is ok, but I find I'm using the LCD more. The fold out design is very functional, but y ... ou could break off the screen if you weren't careful. Wish you could monitor the audio while recording, and adjust the levels. Really if one is serious about quality an outboard recorder would be needed. Also would be great to be able to monitor video through the HDMI port while recording, but no luck there. Haven't tried the AV output whether works while recording. The cam will record AVCHD continuously for as long as chip and battery hold out. Highest quality, 1080p/16 gig chip runs about an hour and 15 minutes. Recording of concerts and plays would be practical. If you're used to a real prosumer video camera you'll have to scale down your expectations, yet it's still a lot for the money, and careful work should yield surprising results. The still pictures are excellent for my use because I don't print bigger than 8x10, and scale down a lot for email and web. The steady shot in the lens really does work well. The cam feels a little frail and light, but everything works and if you don't drop, it should keep going. All in all I'm looking forward to getting to know this little cam better. I think it's going to work out fine. expand » « collapse
Item.HelpfulCount: 1 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: For years, I've struggled with and contemplated the convenience of carrying a smaller point and shoot camera vs. carrying a bulky/heavy full sized SLR. The problem is that the smaller cameras are tempting to take on vacation because of their size but the picture quality is often dissapointing and fails to capture the true ambience of that moment. Conversely, the full sized SLR cameras take excellent pictures but it's size, weight, not to mention cost, make it less appealing to haul around. This is where I introduce the Panasonic FZ 150; it's the perfect compromise of both worlds. By no means am I a professional photographer but the problem with the compact point and shoot type cameras is its' inability to make separate or manual adjustments to the Aperture (opening of the lens), ... shutter speed (length of time the lens remains open during a photo shot) and the ISO/ASA the (film speed rating). I realize that compact cameras have task specific settings i.e. portrait mode, scenery mode, night time mode etc but these modes rely on the camera to make all automatic adjustments and it rarely turns out the way you'd like. You will notice that even on these specialized modes, the picture is often grainy, too light or too dark. In short, ideally, the right amount of light has to travel through the lens for the right amount of time, with the correct depth of field in order for the picture to portray what the human eye sees. With that said, a high quality point and shoot cameras does a descent job in daylight but night time and flash photography is dicey. I've owned many cameras throughout the years but so far, this camera is the best compromise for size, weight and picture quality. It starts with a high quality Leica lens. The optical zoom is impressive and the clarity rivals that of the full size SLR's. Most importantly, this camera is capable of separate and manual adjustments to the aperture, shutter speed and ISO/ASA settings which means that I choose the factors that dictate the picture quality. Additionally, this camera is capable of shooting full 1080i HD video and the quality of the video is impressive. This camera has all of the manual adjustments available on a full size SLR. The main difference is that the high end SLR's have greater range of adjustments and more specialized capabilities for professional photography. If you're like me, casual photo enthusiast, you'll probably never need that range in flexibility. Also keep in mind that the lens on this camera is fixed, meaning that you won't be able to change out to a more specialized or specific lens for longer zooms, wide angles etc. In conclusion, if size, weight and cost is of no concern, then get the full size SLR. At the end of the day, the picture quality from the full size SLR is the best. If you don't care about picture quality but just want something simple to take casual photos, stick with the compact point and shoot. If you're in the market for a mid sized, well priced camera that takes excellent pictures, then look no further. I hope this helps. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I'm really impressed with this camera thus far. This is the perfect compromise between the compact point and shoot models and the full size SLR's. The point and shoot cameras have limited flexibility in terms of adjusting the camera's settings such as the Aperture, ASA/ISO and Shutter Speeds. The ability to adjust such settings makes all the difference in the world between quality photo shots and poorly exposed shots. Generally, I found that the pre-set portrait, scenery, night time and sports settings on point and shoot cameras often yield mediocre results and even worse in low light conditions. With the full size SLR's they take awesome pictures but I find them to be a bit bulky and heavy to lug around, especially on hikes and such. I've been looking for a slightly m ... ore compact version that's capable of taking high quality pictures. This Panasonic camera is an excellent all around camera. It starts with the Leica lens which is high quality and capable of taking fantastic photos. The color presentation is fabulous, clarity crystal clear and it's really easy to use. Best of all, it's capable of the finer adjustments comparable to that of the more common full size SLR's. Another bonus is that this camera has dual capabilities as a video recorder with full 1080 HD quality videos. If you're a casual photo enthusiast like me but want a camera that's capable of taking great photos without the inconvenience of bulk and $$$$, this camera is a great alternative. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: - Good picture quality - Can take RAW images - 1080p 60p with no limits on how much you can record (only limit is battery and memory). - Not much noise in shooting night shots. - Build quality is nicer than some competitors - 460K LCD - nice grip and fits nice in my hands. - Comes with hood and neck strap; isnt bad at all.
Cons: - Not many creative filters (HDR/Selective color or Color Accent, etc.) - 24x Optical zoom seems low compared to 35x and others. - EVF is a bit laggy but thats just me.
Not deducting any eggs because of picky cons.
I commend Panasonic for listening to reviewers and buyers to improve the image quality and features on the new FZ150.
Hoping that they add creative filters/features to new Super-Zoom.

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I have been looking for a possible replacement to my heavy and cumbersome DSLR equipment to take on mountain hikes. Having previously owned two earlier Panasonic 'super-zoom' FZ models, I had an idea of what to expect regarding user functions and how the camera fundamentally would operate. Thus, this purchase decision was easy (given B&H's easy, no-fuss return policies). Image quality is excellent; clearly exceeded my expectations. I shoot only RAW. The FZ150 gives me what I want. With a remote control port, I can use this camera just as I would use my heavy, expensive DSLR equipment. I am very pleased. The lens is really good. The image stabilization system works terrific. The adjustable (position) LCD is a nice feature. Video looks great (albeit I have not used it much). Just a f ... ew complaints. The size of the 4-way controller on the back which gets heavy use is too small. I'd like it to be a little bigger (to be fair, my hands are very big). Also, when reviewing images, lens barrel retracts to the off position. This can be an issue (pinched fingers) with the supplied lens hood if the hood is mounted in the reverse (for storage) position. Viewfinder diopter adjustment will not lock; it can get out of adjustment too easy. Would also prefer a manual zoom control. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: All the functions of a DSLR in a point and shoot packet. Great photos even in low light. Good battery life. Easy to use and understand.
Cons: Price. Close to that of a entry level DSLR Lack of F-Stops, 2.8-8.0 W, 5.2-8.0 T This is not really a con, mosty me but the thumb wheel on back which controls your EV, Aperture and Shutter speed took some getting use to I got a big thumb.
This camera is about as close as your going to get to a DSLR in a point and shoot camera but the cost being so close to that of a entry level DSLR may make some past it by. It's really up to you want your wanting to do. For me I'm happy with it and it dose all I want and then some. As a side note I'v not done enough video recording so I can't comment on this yet. Once again thanks ... Newegg for quick shipping! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I like this camera and have been comparing it to others for a year. I recommended it often when asked what camera to get. It has setting that makes it an excellent point and shoot. It also has controls for many features found on DSLRs. I finally bought it for myself and used it at the McChord air show. Shot fast action at 12 fps and made high definition videos as well as snapshots of family with planes. Comes with software that is outstanding for making slide shows to DVDs to share. Camera fit in a cargo pocket and performs like a big camera with a telephoto.

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I use this in a wide variety shooting condition. What an improvment from my FZ28! Longer and wider zoom, but the compactness feels great, especially I travel alot with it. Love the very large articulated screen. Great HD video indoors and outdoors. Better controls, overall it is really great. Would be nice to have a larger sensor, but I do not print anything larger than 8x10. Battery life is OK, but probably will need a second battery for long trips.

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: Having gradually stepped up from the Lumix LX1 (as an early adopter) to the LX5 in search of the perfect one-lens run-and-gun camera, I ordered the FZ150 for the 24X zoom (this is a fantastic lens!), the dedicated mic input (the RODE VideoMic is perfect on this!) and the hinged screen/EVF option (love it!). Those amazing features are more than a fair trade for the increased bridge size, when using it as a travel shooter. The ergonomic & utilitarian design of this camera is fantastic -- except for ONE boneheaded thing: the tripod mounting screw socket is located very close to the battery/SD card door hinge, as opposed to in the center of the camera, under the lens. This prevents ANY changing of batteries or loading/unloading of SD cards when the camera is on a tripod or attached to a qu ... ick-release mount. This oversight is baffling, considering the location of the tripod socket on both of my LX models allowed the door to open when mounted. Completely detaching the camera to check the memory card in the middle of a shoot is pretty obnoxious, having not had to before. Other than that, though, it's a great camera for the price. Oh, and the Lumix DMW-LWA52 wide angle conversion lens (marketed for the LX5) works on this camera perfectly -- without an adaptor or having to switch to manual focus! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: Simply the best point and shoot camera on the market at this time. I purchased this camera specifically for the video capture capabilities. 1080p at 60fps. I've shot quite a few videos and all I can say is WOW. Very good quality even in low light. Photo's are fantastic and the zoom is quite good at 24X although not as high as some of the competitors. One feature you won't find on the others is 220fps high speed video, great for perfecting that golf swing and the ability to capture non-compressed (RAW) photos.
Cons: I have yet to find a real flaw with this camera. The software that comes with the camera isn't the greatest but it is functional. You have a choice between Apple's mpeg4 mov files or the new AVCHD mts formats. The latter of which is difficult to edit without some sp ... ecial tools.
Even though this is a bit higher in cost compaired to the FZ47, the new sensor does a great job in noise reduction. The friends that have seen the videos taken from this camera have all commented on the fantastic clarity. The optical stabilization is nothing short of amazing. If you've ever tried to hold a camera still by hand for more than 15 minutes you'll come to appreciate how well this stabilization works. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: One of the best superzoom midranges.
Item.Review: So far I've mostly taken photos of birds, but also planes, helicopters, and indoor, static product shots. The thing that makes this camera is definitely the zoom, but also the great lens from Leica. No distortion or fringing. This camera is super easy to use and understand to take basic photos, with a ton of modes for getting creative or helping get the shot right. Very intuitive and plenty of easy-access buttons to get to the function you need right away. The only negatives I have to report so far are the low resolution of the electronic viewfinder makes it a little hard to judge focus there; things are a bit grainy in the EVF, and the fact that you only get a video signal out the HDMI port in playback mode. Would be nice to capture live video direclty to the HDMI output port.

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I haven't had much time with the camera but am slowly learning the different features. I have been able to take indoor shots without using flash which I love as I am not a fan of bright flash. The zoom works very well and has allowed me to take close up pictures of the grandchildren without being in their face. The video is truly sharp. My only complaint is that the tulip shade showed up in some of my shots when not using the zoom. If you don't want the weight and hassle of a dslr then this is the camera for you. I read multiple reviews online and this was the highest rated for a reason.

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: Travel, portraits, and art photos are my uses of this camera. My first Panasonic camera was the FZ 30. I bought the FH 20 to travel light and the TS 10 for snorkeling. After using the FZ 150 for a month I agree with the positive reviews. Pictures are sharp, new features are excellent, access to these features are easy, intelligent automatic and the multiple positions of the screen are helpful. Two negatives: The compact design causes buttons to be pushed accidentally. The barrel zoom and focus has been replaced with a single switch that is close to the manual switch. In a rush it is easy to push the wrong one.

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: At home and travel. Compare to typical DSL, FZ150 is light weight and small enough to carry around. Easy to operate. Fast recharge. Great in low light. The flip/ turn around 3 monitor helps to take group pic. Take crispy clear pictures. The zoom really worked. beautiful body and strong built. The price is reasonable with all the features and the quality. A best camera I ever owned. I recommand it to anybody who likes to take photos. Good job, Panasonic! I will buy another one for my daughter.

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: This camera is easy to use and has so many different options...I read tons of reviews before deciding on this one and im glad i chose it. Pictures come out clear and the burst mode is a big bonus on this camera. I love that the back flips out, and the zzom is amazing. This camera will get to go where my DSLR isnt allowed like concerts. I cant wait till the next one to use it there! Good in low light too!!! Battery life is VERY good also!!! I havent tried the video yet but when I do Ill come back to let you know how it works...

Item.Item: Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ150 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Love the zoom, be aware of focu
Item.Review: I'm a camera enthusiast, and usually stay with Nikon and Canon cameras. I have multiple dSLRs and purchased the long-awaited Canon S100 ($429) for a more portable camera. I was sorely disappointed with indoor pictures and lack of zoom. I sold the Canon on eBay and after lots of research, I'm happy I purchased this Panasonic as a replacement. Images are sharp, but you have to be aware of where the lens is focusing. Depending on the settings, focus in on faces or in the center of the frame. You should read the manual and get used to how to focus and recompose your images. Other than this one glitch, I love all the auto settings, RAW image option, and manual controls. This camera is lightweight and easily portable in my purse. The long zoom makes this camera a fantastic all-around cam ... era for everything from indoor events to landscapes to far-away, fast-moving sports. I've decided it is the best compromise between a limitations of a pocket-size camera and the weight/bulk of a dSLR. ... expand » « collapse

Actually bought the Nikon P500 and returned it, but it wasn't too bad, just didn't have lcd protection and focused weird on long zoom.
